Massacres in Darfur: In el-Fasher, Sudan, 'we are witnessing mass atrocities through our screens'
subhead: Massacres, which have been filmed and shared on social media, have taken place in the capital of North Darfur since the city was seized by the Rapid Support Forces, led by General Mohammed Hamdan Dagalo.

title: Melissa headed to Bermuda, while Haiti, Jamaica and Cuba pick up the pieces
Tunisia's government clamps down on civil society
subhead: The authorities have suspended two of the country's most high-profile organizations. Dozens more are under investigation, accused of receiving foreign funding. President Kais Saied's increasingly repressive regime is unleashing an unprecedented crackdown against civil society.

title: 2026 budget bill: Voting likely delayed as wealth tax is set to be debated on Friday
subhead: The slow pace of debates, due to a proliferation of amendments, has made it unlikely that MPs will vote on the first part of the bill on November 4 as planned. The government has stuck to its decision to favor parliamentary debate and forgo forcing the budget bill through Parliament.

title: French economy's unexpected rebound, driven by aircraft, pharmaceutical, defense exports
subhead: Business activity boosted France's GDP, which rose by 0.5% in the third quarter. However, households remained highly cautious, spending little and investing even less. The late-summer upturn is unlikely to last.

title: 'Airbnb has shaped the idea that everything can be monetized. It's a logic of constant optimization'
subhead: 'The Airbnb Ogre' (2/6). In Paris, about one-third of the listings available on Airbnb have been removed from the 'permanent' housing market, which contributes to the housing crisis in the French capital, explains researcher Jeanne Richon in an interview with Le Monde.

How Airbnb made France its favorite destination, with more than one million listings
subhead: 'The Airbnb Ogre' (1/6). In 15 years, the platform has established itself in France, the leading tourist destination, thanks to effective lobbying and favorable tax conditions. It has even worsened the housing crisis. The company is now expanding its offerings to continue its growth.
byline: By Véronique Chocron and Jessica Gourdon

title: Too old to get a job, too young to retire: The French women over 50 stuck in limbo
subhead: In France, 21% of people aged 55-61 struggle to find work but are unable to retire. Women, who suffer more from societal inequalities throughout their career, are particularly at risk.

title: Three exhibitions in Paris celebrate 100 years of Art Deco
subhead: To mark the centenary of the International Exhibition of Modern Decorative and Industrial Arts, three venues are showcasing a leading figure of the movement, the archives of a renowned trunk-maker and contemporary creations.
